questions.neutral: No signals reach here, do they?

hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: No, nothing gets through here, it seems.
Not much to do but keep old habits going.
I restore typewriters. Keeps me occupied.
Harder now with all the disruptions lately.
Feels quiet, which is rare now.
I work with antique typewriters—restoration mostly.
Safer than most pastimes, I suppose.
Recent events made it tougher to find supplies though.
Not everyone appreciates old machines these days.
No signals and no system eyes.
I spend my time restoring typewriters, from before all the tech.
It's precise work—mechanical, predictable.
I keep a handwritten journal too, just in case.
People started reading BCI logs aloud in my building. Distracting, honestly.
Hard to focus when history’s being read out loud through the window.
Quiet here, like my flat before the BCI trouble.
I restore old typewriters—Zetas, Underwoods, anything mechanical.
Did it before the city became obsessed with transparency.
The hum of a carriage return is comfort, not surveillance.
Last week, I tried journaling on one while someone read BCI logs outside.
For years, this was the only way to talk privately to myself.
Now, privacy feels fragile, like a worn ribbon almost out of ink.
No signals, no Council eyes—reminds me of before the Index.
I restore and collect typewriters. Been at it decades, back when leaders still campaigned.
There’s satisfaction in returning a stubborn spring or cleaning a platen.
I used to document Council schedules by hand—habits linger.
After Halden’s death and those intervention leaks, people shout logs in the courtyard.
Yesterday I tried to journal, but voices outside made it feel risky—even handwriting.
Sometimes I tuck my thoughts under false receipts—old habits from when even paper felt watched.
Feels strange: everyone’s demanding truth, but honest ink feels more dangerous than ever.
hobby_answer: Yes. Nothing too ambitious, just cleaning the Zeta.
Machines are quieter lately. Helps pass the time, that.
People outside, though, rather noisier now than before.
No shortage of stories since Halden's files went public.
Strange days. Easier to focus when no one's looking.
Another Zeta, yes. Needs a lighter touch this time.
Typebars get stuck less when people aren’t streaming every move.
Hard to ignore the noise now that the logs are everywhere.
Noticed more folks trying to scribble things down by hand.
All this truth talk makes old keys feel almost... subversive.
Got the Zeta running, though ribbon's nearly out.
Restoring these things has always been my escape, especially of late.
With everyone buzzing about intervention logs, the lobby’s noisier than my tools.
Strange—handwriting feels less private with street tribunals outside.
Still, a manual carriage return is the best kind of certainty.
Always loved the click. Now, I almost need it.
Not as easy to keep to myself with all this talk of BCI.
Yes, a Zeta again. Restoring them is habit—one that brings a kind of order.
I’ve been jotting notes during repairs, but lately I hesitate.
People are broadcasting BCI stories from patios, drowning out my ribbon work.
I worry a typed page could draw attention some days, even now.
Saw a neighbor watching my window yesterday—paranoid, maybe, but who can say?
This city feels more exposed with the secrets out in open air.
Sometimes I hide finished sheets under fake receipts now.
Not all repairs are for the machines, if you follow.
Yes, a battered Zeta this week. Reminds me of older times—before the mandates.
Restoring typewriters started as nostalgia. Now it’s resistance, in a small way.
After Halden’s logs dropped, felt everyone’s secrets rattling through my building.
I once kept detailed journals—careful, coded, a habit from old Council days.
These days, I stash my notes in service manuals, just to be safe.
Sometimes, the clack of the keys draws more attention than I’d like.
People shout their stories outside now, but I trust ink over voices.
With the Council exposed, privacy’s a myth. All we have is what we hide.
Strange—old ribbons carry truer histories than any minister or index ever did.
